money.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: what you earn by working and can use to buy things. Money can be in the form of notes and coins or cheques, and can be kept in a bank
money.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Don’t spend all your money on the first day of your holiday!
The repairs will cost quite a lot of money.
money.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: money in the form of coins or notes that you can carry around with you
money.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: You’ll find some money in my purse.
I didn’t have any money on me (=I was not carrying any money).
We can change some money at the airport  (=change it into the money of another country).
Don’t forget to get some Swiss money before you leave.
money.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: someone’s wealth, including all the property and other things they own
money.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The family made their money in the woollen trade.
He had lost all his money gambling.
money.translation[0].note_box[0].section: I didn’t have enough money to pay for it.
She makes a little money by babysitting.
More money should be spent on training.
cost money/cost a lot of money
Good food doesn’t have to cost a lot of money.
Companies fired workers to save money.
The farm was beginning to make money at last.
The movie didn’t attract audiences and lost money for the studio.
Has he paid the money he owes you?
My dad lent me money to buy a car.
They arranged to borrow money from the bank to buy a house.
Don’t waste your money on a computer that doesn’t have enough memory.
The Christmas fair raises money for the school.
She had saved up enough money to buy a car.
We regret that we are unable to refund money on tickets.
All the money went on doctor’s bills.
Rob wasn’t working for a while, so we had less money coming in.
All of Dawson’s money came from drugs.
Preston earns good money as a lawyer.
For many, selling drugs seems like easy money.
We had £500 spending money saved for our holiday.
How much pocket money do you get?
More  taxpayer’s money should be spent on the railways.
£10,000 seemed a huge sum of money to me.
Fancy clothes for a baby are a waste of money.
The holiday was excellent value for money.
money.translation[0].note_box[1].section: what you use to buy things, in the form of notes or coins
He spent all his money on computer equipment.
cash
money in the form of coins and notes
I didn’t have any cash with me.
currency
the money used in a particular country
The dollar gained in value against other currencies.
a single European currency
money in the form of coins of low value
Do you have any small change?
a pocketful of loose change
note
a piece of paper money
a £20 note
a $5 bill
coin
a flat round piece of metal used as money
She put some coins in the parking meter.
He took a coin out of his pocket.
a ten-pence/50-cent etc piece
a coin worth a particular amount
money.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: coins, BANKNOTEs and BANK DEPOSITs (=money held in banks) used to buy things and to show their value
money.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: People are eating out less to save money.
Americans spent more money even though they earned less.
You should borrow money from the bank to pay for your course.
As an estate agent, he made (=gained) a lot of  money buying houses cheaply and reselling them.
He has picked a difficult time to raise money (=obtain it for a particular purpose) from outside investors.
money.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: all the money that a country, organization, or person owns
money.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The business collapsed and we lost all our money.
money.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: a plan to inject money into the company
foreigners who wanted to put money into (=invest in) US stocks
money.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: used to talk about what it costs to borrow money
money.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: used to talk about the MONEY SUPPLY (=the amount of money in the economy at a particular time)
money.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: money paid by someone to prove that they are serious about buying something or about doing business
money.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: in OPTIONS TRADING (=buying and selling the right to buy shares etc at a later date for a particular price), an option is at the money when the EXERCISE PRICE (=the price at which the shares etc can be bought using the option) is the same as the MARKET PRICE (=the current price of the shares on the stockmarket). A CALL OPTION (=the right to buy particular shares) is in the money when the exercise price is below the market price and out of the money when it is above it
